programs, to ensure our products continue to be manufactured safely and reliably, and to

nceline on three 
sides.  To the rear there is approximately one thousand feet of undeveloped land to the 
shore of Newark Bay.  Catastrophic failure of the tank due to physical impact or 
impingement by fire are the two primary worst-case loss scenarios.  All chemical 
processing facilities in the area of the isobutylene tank are protected by automatic 
sprinkler or deluge systems, and a high pressure water cannon is in the immediate 
vicinity of the isobutylene tank holding area.   The tank is protected by controlling traffic 
in the area and by the use of concrete jersey barriers, which are ringed around the tank.

The Newark Fire Department is a paid force specializing in industrial facilities.  The 
typical response time for fires in the area is about 5 to 10 minutes.

The facility's process safety management program is organized in a manner consistent 
with the OSHA PSM rule.  The accident prevention program requirements of RMP 
closely follow the programs in place to comply with PSM.  These programs help to 
ensure the safe operation and maintenance of our chemical processes, and prevent and 
mitigate potential accidents involving regulated and other hazardous chemicals.  Key 
features of the Firchem accident prevention program are described below.

Process Safety information of all types is gathered and retained in designated locations.  
Examples include MSDS's, in-house reactivity and stability data, chemical compatibility 
matrices, process chemistry and hazards, P&ID's, electrical classification, equipment 
drawings and specifications, and interlock descriptions.  This information is made 
available for process hazard analyses and for the development of other process safety 
elements.  

Process hazard analyses (PHA's) are conducted on both PSM regulated and non-
regulated processes, with the level of detail commensurate with the hazards.  PHA's 
utilize both HAZOP and What-if techniques.  Multidisciplinary PHA teams are 
ass

embled, including a trained team leader, engineering, research & development, 
production supervision and production operators.  A tracking system for 
recommendations is used to ensure recommendations are addressed.  Revalidations are 
initiated at intervals of five years or less.

Batch procedures are used extensively by operators as step-by-step instructions in the 
regulated multi-purpose batch processes.  These procedures are carefully developed from 
pertinent process safety information.  Where possible, sophisticated computer 
programming is applied to run the operations, which improves process reliability, quality, 
and safety.  This allows production personnel to focus on troubleshooting and other 
higher level tasks.

Personnel operating chemical processes have been trained in their job tasks and 
responsibilities by working side-by-side with more experienced operators, use of outside 
training materials, and consultation with supervisory personnel.  Supervision evaluates 
the performance of employees to determine when they are prepared to operate 
independently.  Safe work practices, such as equipment release, lockout/tagout, confined 
space entry, have been developed.  These are occasionally reviewed and updated as 
needed. 

A fully qualified maintenance staff performs repairs and inspections on equipment and 
instrumentation used in regulated chemical processes, using manufacturers' or internal 
procedures.  Where specialized skills or certifications are needed, appropriate outside 
crafts are used.  A system has been developed to define PSM-critical equipment, to 
ensure designated equipment is maintained at the highest integrity level.  A computerized 
maintenance system has been installed to manage maintenance activities and records 
retention.

Firchem has instituted a management of change procedure to ensure changes to 
equipment, procedures, etc. are evaluated for safety implications, properly authorized and 
documen

Chem Fleur RMP Executive Summary

The Chem Fleur. Firchem Chemical Manufacturing Center is located on an 
approximately 18 acre industrial site in a secluded area of Port Newark.  The location is 
bounded to the East by Newark Bay, on the South by marshlands and the New Jersey 
Turnpike, to the West by an over the road trucking company terminal, and to the North 
by a CONRAIL railhead and new car storage facilities.

The Firchem Chemical Manufacturing Center produces a variety of specialty chemicals 
for the Flavor & Fragrance industry.  A number of our products are manufactured 
through chemical processes regulated under the OSHA Process Safety Management rule 
(OSHA 1910.119).  One of these processes is also regulated under the EPA Risk 
Management Program.  The facility must also comply with other federal, state, and local 
safety and environmental regulations, as well as internal company standards.  We conduct 
our business with the highest priority on the safety and health of our employees, 
customers, and the general public, as well as on the protection of the environment.  

The site is regulated under the USEPA RMP rules for use of one flammable liquified 
petroleum gas (LPG) material Isobutylene (2-Methylpropene or [-Propene, 2-methyl-] 
CAS #115-11-7).  Isobutylene is used in one process known as DDD.  The isobutylene 
is used as a reactant in the DDD manufacturing process.  The isobutylene is purchased 
from ExxonMobil and received and stored on-site in an industry standard transportation 
LPG trailer designed and operated to comply with all US Department of Transportation 
(DOT) safety regulations and specifications.  The material is onsite for about 4 weeks or 
about 8% of the year.

The storage tank is located in an isolated area of the plant and in plant structures 
including a 500,000-gallon firewater tank, and three process buildings 55 feet high 
provide a substantial buffer between the storage area and the plant fe

ted.  Affected personnel review  documentation of process changes that affect 
their work area.  The procedure has mechanisms to ensure that process safety information 
affected by a process change is properly updated. 

Pre-startup safety reviews are conducted on new and modification projects to ensure that 
these projects are constructed per design and safe to operate.   

Compliance auditing of Firchem's process safety management programs is performed at 
least every three years.  Recommendations arising from the audit and their resolutions are 
documented and retained, as specified.

Firchem has a procedure in place to investigate all accidents resulting in injury and 
incidents with serious potential consequences.  Several employees have been trained in 
incident investigation, and these people are used as investigation team leaders.  
Investigations are designed to identify root causes of incidents, and recommendations to 
prevent recurrence.  Written reports are prepared and distributed for review by affected 
personnel, and recommendations monitored until completed.

Employee participation is addressed in several ways.  First-line production employees are 
required participants in process hazard analyses of regulated processes, and they are also 
present in most non-regulated PHA's.  Employees are also encouraged to participate in 
operator training, safety committee, review of batch operating procedures, and in the 
development of other elements of the process safety program.

The facility has established procedures and permits to manage hot work.

Firchem uses a variety of outside contractors, and selects contractors based on a variety 
of characteristics including cost, reliability, quality, and safe work.  Employee contacts 
coordinate contractor training, including potential hazards and emergency evacuation 
procedures.
